newsitem.title: USA: Healthdyne says court upholds rights plan.
newsitem.headline: Healthdyne says court upholds rights plan.

text.p: Healthdyne Technologies Inc said Monday that the U.S. District Court in Atlanta upheld the continuing directors provision of its shareholder rights plan and invalidated Invacare Corp's proposed bylaw amendment to circumvent that provision.
Under the continuing directors provision, only the current board of directors can redeem or amend the rights plan.

Healthdyne said the court also ruled that Invacare's bylaw would infringe upon the board's discretion, under Georgia law, to determine the terms of the rights plan and therefore cannot be submitted to shareholders for a vote at the annual meeting.

The court ruled that Invacare did not succeed in proving that the continuing directors provision is invalid and concluded that Healthdyne had not breached its fiduciary duties under Georgia law, the company said.
Under the court's decision, Healthdyne said, Invacare cannot eliminate the shareholder rights plan even if it wins the proxy contest.
Invacare had filed a notice of its intention to appeal the court's decision, the company said.

It also said that it was continuing to actively explore alternatives to Invacare's offer. Chairman Parker Petit said in a statement, "While nothing is certain, we hope to announce a value enhancing transaction in the next several weeks."

The company said it expects to report "strong" operating results for the second quarter as a result of its new higher profit-margin products and expects the trend to continue later this year and in 1998.

Invacare, which has launched a $200 million hostile offer for Healthdyne, has started a proxy battle to oust Healthdyne's board of directors at the July 30 annual meeting. Healthdyne has repeatedly rejected Invacare's bids, calling them inadequate.
